noun.description: The number of points, goals, runs, etc. achieved in a game or by a team or an individual.
examples: the final score was 25–16 in favor of Washington

noun.description: A group or set of twenty or about twenty.
examples: a score of men lost their lives in the battle
Doyle's success brought imitators by the score

noun.description: A written representation of a musical composition showing all the vocal and instrumental parts arranged one below the other.
A notch or line cut or scratched into a surface.

verb.description: Gain (a point, goal, run, etc.) in a competitive game.
examples: Penn State scored two touchdowns in the fourth quarter
Martinez scored on Anderson's sacrifice fly

verb.description: Orchestrate or arrange (a piece of music), typically for a specified instrument or instruments.
examples: the Quartet Suite was scored for flute, violin, viola da gamba, and continuo

verb.description: Cut or scratch a notch or line on (a surface)
examples: score the card until you cut through

verb.description: Examine (experimentally treated cells, bacterial colonies, etc.), making a record of the number showing a particular character.

phrases: Those people can feel the fine balance between linear and interactive, between rules and freedom, between keeping score and not keeping score.
Managing a game is not simply blowing the whistle when an infringement occurs and keeping the score and time.
The variety of techniques used for keeping score in games is extremely diverse.
Each parent is involved in the sport - her mother is a competitor's steward and her father referees and keeps score at events.
From time to time I have read critical comments about the means of keeping score provided in some board games.
origin: Late Old English scoru set of twenty, from Old Norse skor notch, tally, twenty, of Germanic origin; related to shear. The verb ( late Middle English) is from Old Norse skora make an incision.
